instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.PP1V35_CAM: What is PP1V35_CAM? PP1V35_CAM is a 1.35v power rail to power the webcam. .
definitions.PP1V8_CAM: What is PP1V8_CAM? PP1V8_CAM is a 1.8v power rail for powering the webcam.
definitions.PP3V3_WLAN: What is PP3V3_WLAN? PP3V3_WLAN is a 3.3v power rail that powers the wifi circuit or wifi card. This can go missing when the inductor acting as a fuse before PP3V3_WLAN blows..
definitions.PP3V3_S3RS0_CAMERA: What is PP3V3_S3RS0_CAMERA? PP3V3_S3RS0_CAMERA is a 3.3 volt power rail that powers the camera. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SSD_RESET_L: What is SSD_RESET_L? SSD_RESET_L is a signal that puts the SSD in reset mode when it is low. This means the SSD will not be accessible when this signal is asserted.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v..
definitions.SSD_RESET_CONN_L: What is SSD_RESET_CONN_L? SSD_RESET_CONN_L is a signal that goes to the SSD that will put it in RESET mode which will keep it from working, when SSD_RESET_L is present. _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message:
Hello,

I've got here <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that turns on to a questionmark folder with known good drives (with High Sierra installed and running on different machine). It will also not find any wifi network in boot selection menu. USB is fully functional. 

I bought this machine with no video issue, but that was just L8300 killed by bad LVDS cable - after changing those two things, it worked well. However the screen was in bad shape, so I ordered a new one. After changing the screen it stopped booting from SSD (just questionmark folder, even with known good drives), so I tried to do an internet recovery, but that immediately gave me 1005F error (even after PRAM/SMC reset), so the wifi also doesn't work. I think it's a PCIe issue, probably caused by bad camera in that new screen assembly. However I also changed SSD at once with the screen and the resistance measurements on camera connector are the same as on known working one, so I'm not certain what caused this issue and if the camera is really defective. The board looks pristine, no spills, oxidation, missing parts, signs of previous repairs or anything like that. I only found a little solder ball next to <CHIP>U3711</CHIP>, so I changed it just to be sure, but that did not solve anything. I also changed <CHIP>U1900</CHIP>, no progress.

I've got here another <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> with <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is fully working, so I can compare my measurements. 

All the rails are present and stable, including these: 

<SIGNAL>PP1V8_CAM</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V35_CAM</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_CAM</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3RS0_CAMERA</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_WLAN</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0SW_SSD_FLT</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>CAM_PCIE_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>TBT_PCIE_RESET_L</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_Q_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL>

<SIGNAL>CAM_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> is low, but that should appear after successful boot to OS according to the other machine (?)

These components are not shorted and looks pristine:

CAM
<CAPACITOR>C4030</CAPACITOR> - <CAPACITOR>C4033</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C4061</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C4062</CAPACITOR>

AP
L3501
SSD
<CAPACITOR>C3710</CAPACITOR> - <CAPACITOR>C3717</CAPACITOR>

TBT
<CAPACITOR>C2800</CAPACITOR> - <CAPACITOR>C2807</CAPACITOR>
<CAPACITOR>C2840</CAPACITOR> - <CAPACITOR>C2847</CAPACITOR>

I've already seen this issue on different 3787/3662, but there was always some bad cap... on this one I don't know what else to look for :(

Thank you

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message:
"All the rails are present and stable, including these:
<SIGNAL>AP_CLKREQ_Q_L</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL>"
If you mean 3V, that's bad.
"L" at the end means signal active low (0V).
As these are clock request signals, should be activated.
3V means disable signal in this case...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message: Yes, I mean those two are high (3V), not low. But what can cause this? I cannot find almost anything about those <SIGNAL>CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> signals...

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message: All voltages on pins of <CHIP>U3740</CHIP>? SSD must be connected of course.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message:
<CHIP>U3740</CHIP> with good SSD drive connected:

1. 3.42V - <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>
2. 1.00V - <SIGNAL>P3V3SSD_VMON</SIGNAL>
3. 3.31V - <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
4. 3.42V - <SIGNAL>SSD_RESET_CONN_L</SIGNAL>
5. 0.00V - GND
6. 3.28V - <SIGNAL>SSD_PWR_FET_EN</SIGNAL>
7. 0.00V - <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_CONN_L</SIGNAL>
8. 0.00V - <SIGNAL>SSD_CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL>

So I guess connecting the SSD probably solves that "mystery" with <SIGNAL>CLKREQ_L</SIGNAL> being high :))

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message:
2. 1.00V - <SIGNAL>P3V3SSD_VMON</SIGNAL>

Sounds like the culprit...

And why do you think that should be anything else? Did you even look at the diagram before giving bad advice?


I don't see how a bad camera could mess up the PCI really. At this point I really have no idea what this could be. Bring out the scope and see if there is a PCI clock signal present.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message: I don't have oscilloscope yet, I will get one asap

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message:
No Title

OK, got an oscilloscope. Never worked with one, but on a working machine if I measure <SIGNAL>PCIE_CLK100M_SSD_P</SIGNAL> or N, the curve and spikes looks the same as on the working machine.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message: Boot from USB and see if a camera is recognized and if Wifi is recognized.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message: This is really quite confusing for me. I cannot boot from USB->SATA SSD with High Sierra (the other <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> 2014 boots with it, but this one does not even see it), but I can boot from USB flash drive with High Sierra installer, and when I do that, the wifi is working there, and also the disk utility correctly see the internal SSD drive. So why the hell it does not boot from it, is this possibly a BIOS issue? Sorry I know you also asked about camera, but I did not find a way to test it yet, as I can only boot to that macOS installer.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message:
You need to install 10.11 from USB and update from there to run the APFS EFI update. 
WiFi not working in boot menu is usually cause the wrong model year wifi card is in there and the EFI has no driver for it. In OSX it will work normally.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> questionmark folder, no wifi
threads.message:
I feel so lame right now :D. You're right, it works now. I did not realize that I swapped wifi card with the screen assembly and it's from L2013 while the board is M2014. It works again with the original M2014 card. Also I sold the original SSD before the new LCD came to me and there was El Capitan installed, while all the drives I tested had High Sierra with APFS.

It's unbelieveable that you were able to solve it with so much misleading informations. Thank you!
